bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Lunsford D. Fricks, September 1, 1923

div1.p: Carter writes Fricks from a hospital where he is a patient and encloses a memorandum. He anticipates that he will not be doing any more fieldwork and expresses regret that he is not younger, because the work is far from completed.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Lunsford D. Fricks, September 1, 1923
div1.opener:
(Misel)
(Malaria)
Problem
Badin Hospital,
Badin, N. C???
September 1, 1923.
Surgeon Lunsford D. Fricks,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Room 17, Court House Building,
Memphis, Tennessee.
Dear Doctor Fricks:
div1.p:
I am writing Maxcy a long letter, in answer to one of his,
which I have asked him to send to you.

I am enclosing herewith a Memorandum which may interest you.
It is a little hard to be certain of oneself when one is sick abed,
but I think both letter and Memorandum are clear enough for action
should you judge it advisable to take any.

I think I will be back in Washington shortly and able to do
something, though I judge no more field work. I had intended to go
from this place to Bridgewater, but will not attempt it.
I wish I were ten years younger. There is so much to do!
